Award.AwardTitle: Turbulent sediment suspension absent mean flow-induced shear

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1233842
Cowen

The study of sediment suspension and transport has a long history, due to the importance of scour processes in rivers. In the case of rivers and wind-blown sand or snow, the suspension processes are controlled by the turbulence induced by the fluid flow over the boundary - that is, the flow over the bed. However, sediment-suspending flows are often subject to turbulence that was generated away from the boundary, and this type of sediment suspension process has seen very little research. Examples are widely found in environmental and industrial flows. Consider the specific example of the swash zone, the region of the beach that is alternately covered and uncovered by wave run-up and the principal location of coastal erosion. During wave up-rush, turbulence levels are dominated by turbulence advected from breaking waves and generated by bore collapse, while boundary-generated turbulence is relatively small.

A great advantage of laboratory research is the ability to isolate distinct physical processes from the more complex multi-physics reality. It is proposed to carry out a fundamental experimental research program using a unique turbulence facility, developed on a previous NSF project, which generates turbulence by randomly firing an array of jets assembled in an eight-by-eight grid. These jets generate strong turbulence, with very little mean flow. The turbulence propagates away from the array and towards a bed of sand, where suspension due solely to the turbulence occurs. This facilitates the careful study of sediment suspension purely by turbulence. Quantitative imaging (QI) techniques will be used to characterize the details of the turbulence and the sediment grain motions that lead to suspension and ripple formation. The QI measurements will be used to determine the instantaneous turbulence structures responsible for sediment suspension and to specifically investigate the role of both the fluid on the sediment motions and the sediment on the fluid motions. An ensemble mean picture of the turbulent stresses, in space and time, will be constructed, allowing the development of parameterizations of the sediment suspension process appropriate for inclusion in computational models of sediment suspension and transport.

Coastal areas in the United States are heavily populated, vital to local economies, and of strategic importance. Surveys reveal that nearly 90% of U.S. sandy coasts are eroding - on the East Coast at rates on the order of one meter per year. Field measurements of swash zone sediment transport rates as large as 10 kilograms per second per meter of shoreline have been observed; these are significantly higher than those observed farther seawards in the surf zone. The elevated levels are due to a complex interaction of boundary-generated turbulence, mean currents, and strong ambient turbulence levels advected with the wave breaking processes. Swash zone sediment transport represents just one of a range of important flows in which turbulence generated away from the boundary dominates sediment suspension and dynamics. An understanding of turbulent suspension in the absence of mean flows is a critical building block on which better models of sediment suspension can be developed. These will significantly improve our ability to model industrial and environmental erosive and depositional processes. The project will lead to a Ph.D. for a talented woman interested in a faculty career who, along with the PIs, will host an inquiry-based project on environmental transport processes for high-school women considering careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study a unique version of a boundary layer flow.  Boundary layer flow is established when a flow encounters a boundary and is defined as the region where the boundary affects various metrics of the flow through viscosity (friction) and kinematic effects (no flow through the boundary). A river flowing over its bed where the boundary slows the mean flow as the bed is approached is an example of a boundary layer.  A slowing mean flow is not the only way to generate a boundary layer. In flows with turbulence but low mean flow, such as beneath breaking waves or the interacting incurrent and excurrent jets of mussels or clams feeding, or in industrial flows, such as plating and coating deposition processes, the viscous and kinematic effects at the bed damp the turbulence to zero creating a boundary layer. Viscous drag forces on a bed are traditionally determined by considering the gradient in the mean velocity as the bed is approached, which is essentially zero in this boundary layer of interest. However, it is easily observed that turbulent events in the absence of mean flow suspend sediment. Turbulent motions generate significant instantaneous local bed stress and our goal is to understand these processes and parameterize the turbulence requisite to suspend sediment so that computational models of these types of flows may be made considerably more accurate. 

Experiments were performed in our facility designed specifically to generate horizontally homogeneous (i.e., independent of horizontal position within the facility), nearly isotropic (i.e., energetics in all three Cartesian directions essentially the same) turbulence with near zero mean flow. The original RASJA consists of an 8 x 8 grid of jets (driven by bilge pumps), and we built an additional 16 x 16 RASJA to expand the range of turbulence characteristics attainable. By using particle image velocimetry (PIV - an image-based technique that tracks clusters of neutrally buoyant particles as they move within a laser light sheet and produces thousands of temporally resolved velocity vectors on an instantaneous 2-D spatial plane) and acoustic measurements, we characterized the turbulence using standard metrics. We demonstrated that by increasing the mean on-time of the jets we generated more energetic flows with higher levels of turbulent kinetic energy and dissipation rates.  We are able to control the integral length scale of the turbulence, a measure of the larger scales of the turbulence, by varying the mean jet on-time, a valuable and significant finding as this scale is typically set by geometry and hence is a constant once a facility’s geometry is established.

Turbulent dissipation is an important metric of turbulent flows and challenging to measure. The standard approach to its calculation is to assume isotropy and use methods such as those involving structure functions (spatial correlations across turbulent eddies) and spatial spectra (energy content at different eddy sizes). At boundaries, isotropy does not exist. We used our PIV results to directly calculate the dissipation and demonstrate that using the bed-normal velocity component within the standard approaches to calculating dissipation resulted in significant errors while using bed-parallel components resulted in reasonable estimates. Using our dissipation results we calculated the empirical constant in the Tennekes (1975) model of Eulerian frequency spectra. This model allows for the determination of dissipation from temporally resolved single-point velocity measurements when there is no mean flow, so it can be employed in field measurements where spatially-resolved measurements are prohibitively expensive.

We compared the turbulent boundary layers generated by the two RASJAs over solid and sediment boundaries finding a decrease in bed-normal turbulent fluctuations due to the porosity of the sediment bed. We observed the development of orthogonal ripples in the sediment (figure 1), which was truly novel in a facility absent mean shear or oscillations. The ripples cause a further decrease in turbulent fluctuations due to increased drag at the bed. By contrast, in experiments with significant levels of sediment suspension, we observe an increase in the turbulent kinetic energy due to stirring generated by suspended sediment structures, such as bed-attached vortices (figure 2).  We found a linear relationship between the integral length scale of the turbulent flow with the ripple spacing, suggesting that the turbulence induced the ripples. Finally, we developed a method for considering short time bed stress as a metric for understanding the importance of turbulent sediment suspension in a zero-mean shear environment.

This project has introduced 58 young women to aspects of STEM fields and has had an important impact on many of their choices in educational and career path.  One completed her PhD and is shortlisted in current faculty searches, four completed or are in pursuit of their BSc degrees, 53 high school students were exposed to a one-week hands-on project on environmental dispersion processes and one summer high school intern worked on this project.
